journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: The influence of Chine nose shapes on a slender body flight vehicle at high angles of attack

contrib-group.aff: 1School of Mechanical Engineering, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, Republic of Korea
2Wind Energy R&D Center, UNISON Co. Ltd, Daejeon, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: School of Mechanical Engineering, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan 712–749, Republic of Korea. email: djsong@yu.ac.kr

abstract.p: The flow characteristics of asymmetric vortices and the side force of a slender body flight vehicle with chine nose at high angles of attack have been studied using a three-dimensional upwind Navier–Stokes method with the k–ω turbulence model and a simple laminar–turbulent transition model. Asymmetrically changing turbulent viscosities that arise from asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions cause asymmetric cross-flow vortex structures and side forces at higher angles of attack. However, certain type of edges may cause fixed flow separations on these edges. In this study, the chine nose shape with chine edge on its both sides is considered for the method to reduce side force. The asymmetric flow control capacity of chine nose shapes at high angles of attack is studied.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Under very high angles of attack condition (typically >30°) at low subsonic flight velocity, the flow separation and the vortex induce a large, unwanted side force, which greatly affects flight stability, even at a zero sideslip angle. Many researchers have observed this unwanted side force through experimental investigations and termed it a ‘phantom yaw’. These large side forces and asymmetric flow-separations show very irregular patterns that vary with the prevailing conditions [1–3]. Thus, it is difficult to find out the reasons for and the flow structures of these phenomena. The causes of these asymmetric flow-separations are thought to be micro-asymmetries on the surface that result from microscopic imperfections and the uneven conditions of external-flow characteristics. It is clear that unwanted side force is caused by asymmetric flow structure and can be reduced by controlling asymmetric flow separation.

The effects of various laminar–turbulent transition conditions and angles of attack have been examined. The influence of external flow Reynolds number and external flow condition has been investigated by Lamont [4], Ericsson and Reding [5, 6]. Also, it is well known that the maximum side force is often found in the regime of the laminar–turbulent transition of flow. Based on these investigations, the asymmetric flow and side-force characteristics were developed by applying artificially different asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions in a previous study [7].

Through many experimental studies, the existence and trend of the phantom yaw have been ascertained. The effective forebody shapes to reduce the unwanted side force at high angles of attack conditions have been analysed by experimental studies [8, 9]. For practical research purpose, computational fluid dynamics methods can be considered. In prior numerical studies [10–16], various features (e.g. artificially asymmetric geometry, sideslip angle, different surface roughnesses, and rolling) were used to describe the steady asymmetric vortex and the side force at high angles of attack. However, these approaches include artificial modifications of the geometry and flow conditions. As a result, many difficulties arise with regard to the application of these approaches to real and practical problems.

In this study, the method of using artificial and asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions is suggested for describing the steady asymmetric vortex and the side force at high angles of attack. This approach does not include modifications of the flight vehicle geometry and flow conditions. The asymmetric flow and side-force characteristics were developed by applying artificially different asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions. Also, the asymmetric flow control capacity of various nose shapes at high angles of attack is studied. It is well known that asymmetric separations and large side forces are affected by the Reynolds number, the shape of the forebody, and the angle of attack [17, 18]. Specially, the flow structure started from forebody part shows the strongest asymmetry. Also, this partially affects subsequent development of flow on an afterbody.

sec.title: 2 NUMERICAL METHOD
sec.p: The three-dimensional (3D) compressible upwind flux-difference splitting Navier–Stokes method with the k–ω turbulence model [19, 20] is used to compute the flowfields. The current computational method was extensively used by current authors [20–24]. Asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions are set on the surface of the flight vehicle to generate an asymmetric vortex along the vehicle. A message-passing interface library and a PC-cluster system are used to reduce the computational time.

sec.title: 2.1 Test conditions and boundary conditions
sec.p:
Table 1 gives the test conditions for numerical analysis. The Reynolds number based on the base diameter is 440 000 and the angle of attack 50°. This condition belongs to the transition regime by Lamont’s [4] work. Table 1
Test conditions
Angle of attack (α) 50°
ReD 440 000
Mach number 0.3
Air model Perfect gas

The dimensions and details of the tangent-ogive-cylinder model considered here are shown in Fig. 1(a). The length of the forebody is 3.0 times the cylinder diameter (D) and the total length of the flight vehicle is 15.0D. The grid system is shown in Fig. 1(b). For the grid-conversion test (Fig. 2), the grid sensitivity test was performed by increasing the grid points from one to three million [7]. After the grid-convergence tests, the final grid system has about 2.6 million grid points and grid points are distributed more in the circumferential direction than in other directions. Fig. 1
The geometry and the grid system: (a) tangent-ogive-cylinder shape and (b) grid system (120 × 182 × 120) [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics) Fig. 2
Grid-convergence test [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)

sec.title: 2.2 k–ω turbulence model
sec.p: The k–ω model yields more accurate predictions of skin friction coefficient for strong adverse pressure gradient flow compared with k–ε model. However, for the k–ω model, the freestream value of ω produced some effects on boundary layers [25]. Two-equation k–ω turbulence model can be simply written as equations (1) and (2) [26, 27] (1) (2) where β = 3/40, β* = 0.09, σk = 2.0, σω = 2.0, and α = 5/9. Turbulence kinetic energy production Pk and the eddy viscosity are given by (3) (4)

sec.title: 2.3 Asymmetric turbulent transitions
sec.p: In this study, a simple laminar–turbulent transition model is used to generate an asymmetric vortex and a side force. The turbulent viscosity in the transition region is modelled using the turbulent viscosity as calculated by the k–ω turbulence model and the control function (Fs), as shown in equation (5). (5)
The control function, Fs, is based on experimental data that were suggested by Gostelow et al. [28] and is simplified, as shown in equation (6). (6)

In reality, the condition of laminar–turbulent transition is sensitive to many factors of the flow and surface conditions. All factors and variables in Table 2 are generally determined by experimentation. However, the focus of this study is not the various causes of laminar–turbulent transition but the effect of laminar–turbulent transition. Therefore, the factors and the variables of laminar–turbulent transition are simply selected as in Table 2, following the study conducted by Gostelow et al.’s [28] study. Table 2
Factors and variables for the transition model
C1 −0.412
C2 0.10
Tut Turbulence intensity at the starting position of the laminar–turbulent transition
s Fluid-moving position (distance) starting from stagnation position
st Starting position of the laminar–turbulent transition
λ Length of the laminar–turbulent transition region

Figure 3(a) the shows overall flow regime along the body and Fig. 3(b) the cross-flow regime around circular cross-section of typical frustum and the s-direction that is divided from the stagnation position (or windward plane) on the flight vehicle. The starting position and the length of the laminar–turbulent transition region with respect to the cross-flow direction (s-direction) are asymmetrically set to generate an asymmetric flow structure. An asymmetric turbulent viscosity is allowed near the surface of the flight vehicle through these asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition parameters. The magnitude of local side forces is affected by the asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions. Fig. 3
An example of a generated asymmetric transition region: (a) transition region and (b) s-directions [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)

Table 3 gives the different cases of laminar–turbulent transition conditions (refer to Lim et al. [7]). Case 1 features the most delayed fully turbulent condition, under which it is not easy to cause the flow separation. Therefore, Case 1 shows more stable values of the local side force than the other cases. Cases 2 and 3 have regions of fully turbulent flow that are developed earlier than Case 1 does. Therefore, these cases exhibit a greater magnitude of the local side-force. Cases 3 and 4 have the same fully turbulent region; but the asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition regions are different. Case 4 has a smaller λ1 than Case 3. This difference can be accompanied by differing magnitudes of the local side force. Table 3
Laminar–turbulent transition conditions [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
Case 1 Case 2 Case 3 Case 4
st,1 3/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 1/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 3/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)
st,2 4/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 3/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 3/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)
λ1 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 1/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)
λ2 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 2/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)
st,1 + λ1 5/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 3/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 4/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 4/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)
st,2 + λ2 6/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 4/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 5/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°) 5/8πR sin⁡(α)sin⁡(50°)

Thus, the constructed asymmetric turbulent viscosity structure affects the asymmetric flow-separations and the large side force. Figure 4 (a) to (d) shows turbulent transition regions and turbulence viscosity contours at the cross-section. Growth of turbulence viscosity agrees well with laminar–turbulent transition conditions. Fig. 4
Turbulent transition region and turbulence viscosity contours at the cross-section (tangent-ogive forebody, ReD = 440 000, angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 1, (b) Case 2, (c) Case 3, and (d) Case 4

sec.title: 3.1 Effects of asymmetric transition conditions
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows a comparison of the local side-force coefficient distributions at different laminar–turbulent transition conditions with the experimental data of Champigny [29]. The unsteady local side force might be occurred due to the cross-flow instability. The transition patterns on cone with axi-symmetric and 3D boundary layers has been explained with cross-flow velocity profiles (cross-flow streamlines) and lateral pressure distributions in our previous study [7]. In Champigny’s [29] study, the geometry of flight vehicle is tangent-ogive-cylinder shape with 3.0D nose length and flow conditions are the same as in Table 1. The experimental data and numerical simulation results show similar patterns with regard to the local side-force coefficient distribution. In all cases, the maximum local side force appears near the forebody part (x/D < 3). After this region, the local side-force distributions fluctuate and exhibit a dwindling trend. In this study, same asymmetric transition conditions are applied in entire x-direction, which might not be same as real experiment conditions; thus, there were some discrepancies between experiments and computed results. Fig. 5
Comparison of local side-force coefficient distributions (angle of attack = 50°) [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)

Table 4 gives a comparison of the normal-force and the side-force coefficients among the different cases. Case 3 shows the most similar magnitudes of the normal force and the side force as experimental data, when all the cases are compared with the relevant experimental data. The magnitude of the side force and the trend in the local side-force distribution on the slender body of the flight vehicle are sensitive to changes in the laminar–turbulent transition conditions that can be controlled for this purpose. Table 4
Comparison of CN and CY (angle of attack = 50°) [7] (Reprinted with permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
Experimental Case 1 Case 2 Case 3 Case 4
CN 5.6 6.79 4.41 5.59 4.96
CY −6.4 −0.39 −4.11 −5.56 −9.02
|CY |/CN 1.14 0.06 0.93 0.99 1.82

Figure 6 shows the comparisons of the side-force coefficients over the normal-force coefficients at different angles of attack. The computed side-force pattern is changed from gradual increase to decrease at excessively high angles of attack, which is similar to experimental data. Fig. 6
Comparison of |CY |/CN
Exp.1: (ogive: Ln/D = 3.5) [30]
Exp.2: 2-1; Re = 2.8 × 105, 2-2; Re = 4.4 × 105, 2-3; and Re = 9.0 × 105 [29]

sec.title: 3.2 Effects of various forebody shapes
sec.p: In the previous study [7], the asymmetries of flow characteristics were concentrated near the forebody at higher angles of attack. Further, the forebody greatly affected the characteristics of the asymmetric side force and flow patterns. Based on these results, the effective forebody shapes to reduce side force and to obtain stable flow characteristics were studied.

Table 5 shows various axi-symmetric forebody shapes; tangent-ogive, cone, sphere-cone, oval cross-section, and chine cross-section shapes were applied to compare their characteristics of the asymmetric side force and the flow pattern. Table 5
Various axi-symmetric nose shapes
Nose shape Nose length Forebody shape
Tangent-ogive 3.0D
Cone 3.0D
Sphere-cone 3.0D (sphere diameter = 0.5D)
Oval 3.0D
Chine 3.0D

sec.title: 3.2.1 Axi-symmetric bodies: tangent-ogive-cylinder, cone-cylinder, and sphere-cone-cylinder
sec.p:
Table 6 shows a comparison of the normal- and side-force coefficients across the different forebody shape cases of tangent-ogive, cone, and sphere-cone. In these three cases, sphere-cone-cylinder case shows smaller magnitude of the normal- and the side-force. However, the difference in normal- and side-force coefficients is very small. Figure 7 shows the comparison of 3D pathlines. The pathline of three different cases shows asymmetric flow patterns in all cases. The flow separation positions of all cases show asymmetric patterns (Fig. 8). These asymmetric flow characteristics may cause difference in the local side force. Figure 9 shows a comparison of the local side-force coefficient distributions among the different forebody cases of tangent-ogive, cone, and sphere-cone. The cone-cylinder case shows larger deviation of the local side force than the tangent-ogive-cylinder case. Also, the sphere-cone-cylinder case shows smaller deviation of local side force than the tangent-ogive-cylinder case. However, the magnitudes of all the cases do not show big differences. Fig. 7
Pathline near the forebody (top view, laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Fig. 8
Flow separation positions (laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Fig. 9
Comparison of local side-force coefficient distributions (laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Table 6
Comparison of CN and CY
Nose shape Tangent-ogive Cone Sphere-cone
CN 5.59 5.53 5.36
CY −5.56 −5.58 −5.12
|CY |/CN 0.99 1.01 0.96

Based on experimental results, Hunt [31] concluded that blunt nose can reduce the peak value of local side force but the net side force on the afterbody may be increased. This conclusion agrees well with current numerical results.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Tangent-ogive-cylinder, oval cross-section, and chine cross-section
sec.p:
Table 7 shows a comparison of the normal- and the side-force coefficients among the different forebody shape cases of tangent-ogive, oval cross-section, and chine cross-section. The cases of oval and chine forebody shapes have wider width compared with height at the cross-section. In these three cases, oval and chine forebody cases show greatly decreased magnitude of the side force compared with axi-symmetric tangent-ogive-cylinder case. Figure 10 shows the comparison of 3D pathlines. Axi-symmetric tangent-ogive forebody case shows asymmetric flow patterns but oval and chine forebody cases show nearly symmetric flow pattern compared with the tangent-ogive forebody case. Specially, the separation position (Fig. 11) and flow pattern near the forebody part of oval and chine forebody cases show almost symmetric separation positions and pathlines. Figure 12 shows a comparison of the local side-force coefficient distributions among the different forebody shape cases. Oval and chine shape cases show greatly decreased magnitude of side force compared with tangent-ogive-cylinder case. Fig. 10
Pathlines near the forebody (top view, laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Fig. 11
Flow separation positions (laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Fig. 12
Comparison of local side-force coefficient distributions (laminar–turbulent transition condition: Case 3, angle of attack 50°) Table 7
Comparison of CN and CY
Nose shape Tangent-ogive Oval Chine
CN 5.59 5.65 6.17
CY −5.56 −4.41 −4.69
|CY |/CN 0.99 0.78 0.76

sec.title: 3.3 Effects of chined forebody shape
sec.p: The asymmetric flow control capacity of chine nose shapes at high angles of attack is studied. The chine shape is described using ellipse equation, as shown in equation (7). (7) a is the control chine edge shape; b the tangent-ogive shape; D the cylinder diameter; Ln the nose length; X1 the control shape of x–y cross-section; X2 the control sharpness of chine edge.

Table 8 shows the various forebody shapes generated using equation (7). Figure 13 shows the cross-sectional shapes of chined forebody according to the variable X1 that controls the ratio of height and width. Also, Fig. 14 shows the cross-sectional shapes of chined forebody according to the variable X2 that controls the sharpness of chine edge. The case of [X1 = −1.0, X2 = 0.0] shows a similar forbody shape with tangent-ogive-cylinder shape. In this section, side force (CY) and yawing moment coefficient (CYM) are used to evaluate the asymmetric flow control capacity. Also, laminar–turbulent transition conditions for Cases 3 and 4 are applied. Fig. 13
Cross-sectional shapes of chined forebody according to the variable X1 (x/D = 1.0) Fig. 14
Cross-sectional shapes of chined forebody according to the variable X2 (x/D = 1.0) Table 8
Various chine nose shapes
Cross-section (x/D = 1.0) Forebody shape
X1 = −1.0, X2− = 0 (almost tangent-ogive shape)
X1 = 0.5, X2 = 0
X1 = −1.0, X2 = −1.5
X1 = 0.5, X2 = −1.5

sec.title: 3.3.1 Effect of the variable X1 of chine shape function
sec.p: Variable X1 controls the ratio of height and width at the cross-section of forebody. X1 = −1.0 cases have similar ratio of height and width at the cross-section of forebody. Wide width may induce artificial flow separation along both sides of cross-section due to the small radius of curvature.

Figure 15 shows the pathlines of tangent-ogive-cylinder and [X1 = 1.0, X2 = 0.0] cases. In the case of [X1 = 1.0, X2 = 0.0], the pathlines in the front part of forebody show approximately symmetric flow pattern and flow separation position (Fig. 16). This symmetric flow structure can decrease the side force and the yawing moment of flight vehicle. The side-force coefficients (Fig. 17) and the yawing moment coefficients (Fig. 18) were compared according to the variable X1. In the condition of X1 ≥ 0.0, the side force and yawing moment show similar decreased magnitude. The forebody shape with reasonably wide width of cross-section can decrease the asymmetric side force and show stable flow pattern. Fig. 15
Comparisons pathline near the forebody (top view, angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 16
Comparisons of flow separation positions (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 17
Comparisons of side-force coefficients (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 18
Comparisons of yawing moment coefficients (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4

sec.title: 3.3.2 Effect of the variable X2 of chine shape function
sec.p: Variable X2 controls the sharpness of chine edge of forebody. Sharp chine edge can fix flow separation position on it. The forebody shape with X2 = 0.0 does not have sharp chine edge and for X2 = 2.0 forebody shape cannot exist in reality.

Figure 19 shows the pathlines of tangent-ogive-cylinder and [X1 = 1.0, X2 = −1.9] cases. In the case of [X1 = 1.0, X2 = −1.9], the pathlines in the front portion of forebody show approximately symmetric flow pattern and flow separation position (Fig. 20). Sharp chine edge can fix the flow separation positions at the forebody part. This symmetric flow structure can decrease the side force and the yawing moment of flight vehicle. Side-force coefficients (Fig. 21) and yawing moment coefficients (Fig. 22) were compared according to the variable X2. Sharp chine edges can decrease the side force and the yawing moment due to its special shape causing flow separation at the chine edges. However, excessive sharp chine edge at the forebody may cause higher normal force and distorted flow characteristics at the cylinder body. Figure 23 shows the pathlines of the tangent-ogive forebody, [X1 = 1.0, X2 = 0.0] (no chine edge) and [X1 = 1.0, X2 = −1.9] (sharp chine edge). Sharp chine edge case show distorted pathlines at the cylinder body compared with another cases. Fig. 19
Comparisons pathline near the forebody (top view, angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 20
Comparisons of flow separation position (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 21
Comparisons of side-force coefficients (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 22
Comparisons of yawing moment coefficients (angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4 Fig. 23
Comparisons pathline near the forebody (top view, angle of attack 50°): (a) Case 3 and (b) Case 4

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
In this study, the asymmetric flow and side-force characteristics were developed by applying artificially different asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions. Also, the effects of various forebody shapes are examined. The conclusions are as follows.
Effects of asymmetric transition conditions: the results of numerical simulation that are obtained from asymmetric laminar–turbulent transition conditions can yield patterns of the local side-force coefficient distribution and magnitudes of the normal and the side forces that are similar to those of experimental data. In all cases, the maximum local side force appears near the forebody part (x/D < 3). After this region, the local side-force distributions fluctuate and exhibit a dwindling trend. The magnitude and characteristics of the side force on a flight vehicle are sensitive to the factors of the laminar–turbulent transition model. The starting position and the length of the laminar–turbulent transition may control the asymmetric flow pattern and the side force.
Axi-symmetric bodies (tangent-ogive-cylinder, cone-cylinder, and sphere-cone-cylinder): sphere-cone-cylinder case shows reduced peak value of the local side-force. However, the side force magnitude of all cases does not show any big difference. This means that the bluntness of nose is not effective method to reduce ‘phantom yaw’ in slender body flight vehicles.
Tangent-ogive-cylinder, oval cross-section, and chine cross-section: oval and chine shape cases shows greatly decreased magnitude of side force compared with tangent-ogive-cylinder case. Chine nose shape can control the asymmetric vortex and local side-force effectively due to its special shape causing flow separation at the edges of chine shape. Reasonable oval cross-section forebody shape can decrease the asymmetric side force and show stable flow pattern.
Effect of the design variables of chine shape function: the forebody shape with reasonable wide width (X1) of cross-section can decrease the asymmetric side force and show stable flow pattern. Sharp chine edge (X2) can decrease the asymmetric side force and show fixed flow separation position at the forebody part. However, excessive sharp chine edge at the forebody may cause higher normal force and distorted flow characteristics at the cylinder body.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study was supported by a Yeungnam University research grant in 2008.

def.p: overall normal-force coefficient, overall normal force/(qπD2/4)
overall side-force coefficient, which is (overall side force)/(qπD2/4)
local side-force coefficient, which is (local side force)/(qD sin2α)
overall yawing moment coefficient (overall yawing moment)/(qπD3/4)
fluid-moving position (distance) starting from stagnation position
axial distance from the nose tip
turbulent viscosity in the fully turbulent region
turbulent viscosity in the transition region
